metadata.summary: Apple's Human Interface Guidelines documentation for Layout, covering best practices for creating adaptive layouts across all Apple platforms including iOS, iPadOS, macOS, tvOS, visionOS, and watchOS. Includes specifications for device screen dimensions and size classes.

content.description: A large yellow/gold rectangular banner image serving as the hero visual for the Layout documentation page. The image has a solid warm yellow/amber color fill with no text or additional visual elements, representing the visual identity of the Layout section in Apple's design system.
content.purpose: Hero banner identifying the Layout section of HIG documentation

content.text: A consistent layout that adapts to various contexts makes your experience more approachable and helps people enjoy their favorite apps and games on all their devices.

Your app's layout helps ground people in your content from the moment they open it. People expect familiar relationships between controls and content to help them use and discover your app's features, and designing the layout to take advantage of this makes your app feel at home on the platform.
Apple provides templates, guides, and other resources that can help you integrate Apple technologies and design your apps and games to run on all Apple platforms. See Apple Design Resources.

content.guideline: Group related items to help people find the information they want.
content.explanation: For example, you might use negative space, background shapes, colors, materials, or separator lines to show when elements are related and to separate information into distinct areas. When you do so, ensure that content and controls remain clearly distinct.

content.guideline: Make essential information easy to find by giving it sufficient space.
content.explanation: People want to view the most important information right away, so don't obscure it by crowding it with nonessential details. You can make secondary information available in other parts of the window, or include it in an additional view.

content.guideline: Extend content to fill the screen or window.
content.explanation: Make sure backgrounds and full-screen artwork extend to the edges of the display. Also ensure that scrollable layouts continue all the way to the bottom and the sides of the device screen. Controls and navigation components like sidebars and tab bars appear on top of content rather than on the same plane, so it's important for your layout to take this into account.

content.text: When your content doesn't span the full window, use a background extension view to provide the appearance of content behind the control layer on either side of the screen, such as beneath the sidebar or inspector. For developer guidance, see backgroundExtensionEffect() and UIBackgroundExtensionView.

content.guideline: Differentiate controls from content.
content.explanation: Take advantage of the Liquid Glass material to provide a distinct appearance for controls that's consistent across iOS, iPadOS, and macOS. Instead of a background, use a scroll edge effect to provide a transition between content and the control area. For guidance, see Scroll views.

content.guideline: Place items to convey their relative importance.
content.explanation: People often start by viewing items in reading order — that is, from top to bottom and from the leading to trailing side — so it generally works well to place the most important items near the top and leading side of the window, display, or field of view. Be aware that reading order varies by language, and take right to left languages into account as you design.

content.guideline: Align components with one another to make them easier to scan and to communicate organization and hierarchy.
content.explanation: Alignment makes an app look neat and organized and can help people track content while scrolling or moving their eyes, making it easier to find information. Along with indentation, alignment can also help people understand an information hierarchy.

content.guideline: Take advantage of progressive disclosure to help people discover content that's currently hidden.
content.explanation: For example, if you can't display all the items in a large collection at once, you need to indicate that there are additional items that aren't currently visible. Depending on the platform, you might use a disclosure control, or display parts of items to hint that people can reveal additional content by interacting with the view, such as by scrolling.

content.guideline: Make controls easier to use by providing enough space around them and grouping them in logical sections.
content.explanation: If unrelated controls are too close together — or if other content crowds them — they can be difficult for people to tell apart or understand what they do, which can make your app or game hard to use. For guidance, see Toolbars.

content.text: Every app and game needs to adapt when the device or system context changes. In iOS, iPadOS, tvOS, and visionOS, the system defines a collection of traits that characterize variations in the device environment that can affect the way your app or game looks. Using SwiftUI or Auto Layout can help you ensure that your interface adapts dynamically to these traits and other context changes; if you don't use these tools, you need to use alternative methods to do the work.
Here are some of the most common device and system variations you need to handle:

items: Different device screen sizes, resolutions, and color spaces
System features like Dynamic Island and camera controls
External display support, Display Zoom, and resizable windows on iPad
Locale-based internationalization features like left-to-right/right-to-left layout direction, date/time/number formatting, font variation, and text length

content.guideline: Design a layout that adapts gracefully to context changes while remaining recognizably consistent.
content.explanation: People expect your experience to work well and remain familiar when they rotate their device, resize a window, add another display, or switch to a different device. You can help ensure an adaptable interface by respecting system-defined safe areas, margins, and guides (where available) and specifying layout modifiers to fine-tune the placement of views in your interface.

content.guideline: Be prepared for text-size changes.
content.explanation: People appreciate apps and games that respond when they choose a different text size. When you support Dynamic Type — a feature that lets people choose the size of visible text in iOS, iPadOS, tvOS, visionOS, and watchOS — your app or game can respond appropriately when people adjust text size. To support Dynamic Type in your Unity-based game, use Apple's accessibility plug-in (for developer guidance, see Apple – Accessibility). For guidance on displaying text in your app, see Typography.

content.guideline: Preview your app on multiple devices, using different orientations, localizations, and text sizes.
content.explanation: You can streamline the testing process by first testing versions of your experience that use the largest and the smallest layouts. Although it's generally best to preview features like wide-gamut color on actual devices, you can use Xcode Simulator to check for clipping and other layout issues. For example, if your iOS app or game supports landscape mode, you can use Simulator to make sure your layouts look great whether the device rotates left or right.

content.guideline: When necessary, scale artwork in response to display changes.
content.explanation: For example, viewing your app or game in a different context — such as on a screen with a different aspect ratio — might make your artwork appear cropped, letterboxed, or pillarboxed. If this happens, don't change the aspect ratio of the artwork; instead, scale it so that important visual content remains visible. In visionOS, the system automatically scales a window when it moves along the z-axis.

content.text: A layout guide defines a rectangular region that helps you position, align, and space your content on the screen. The system includes predefined layout guides that make it easy to apply standard margins around content and restrict the width of text for optimal readability. You can also define custom layout guides. For developer guidance, see UILayoutGuide and NSLayoutGuide.

A safe area defines the area within a view that isn't covered by a toolbar, tab bar, or other views a window might provide. Safe areas are essential for avoiding a device's interactive and display features, like Dynamic Island on iPhone or the camera housing on some Mac models. For developer guidance, see SafeAreaRegions and Positioning content relative to the safe area.

developerReferences.name: Positioning content relative to the safe area

content.guideline: Respect key display and system features in each platform.
content.explanation: When an app or game doesn't accommodate such features, it doesn't feel at home in the platform and may be harder for people to use. In addition to helping you avoid display and system features, safe areas can also help you account for interactive components like bars, dynamically repositioning content when sizes change.

content.text: For templates that include the guides and safe areas for each platform, see Apple Design Resources.

content.guideline: Aim to support both portrait and landscape orientations.
content.explanation: People appreciate apps and games that work well in different device orientations, but sometimes your experience needs to run in only portrait or only landscape. When this is the case, you can rely on people trying both orientations before settling on the one you support — there's no need to tell people to rotate their device. If your app or game is landscape-only, make sure it runs equally well whether people rotate their device to the left or the right.

content.guideline: Prefer a full-bleed interface for your game.
content.explanation: Give players a beautiful interface that fills the screen while accommodating the corner radius, sensor housing, and features like Dynamic Island. If necessary, consider giving players the option to view your game using a letterboxed or pillarboxed appearance.

content.guideline: Avoid full-width buttons.
content.explanation: Buttons feel at home in iOS when they respect system-defined margins and are inset from the edges of the screen. If you need to include a full-width button, make sure it harmonizes with the curvature of the hardware and aligns with adjacent safe areas.

content.guideline: Hide the status bar only when it adds value or enhances your experience.
content.explanation: The status bar displays information people find useful and it occupies an area of the screen most apps don't fully use, so it's generally a good idea to keep it visible. The exception is if you offer an in-depth experience like playing a game or viewing media, where it might make sense to hide the status bar.

content.description: An iPhone screenshot showing an iOS app interface with a pink/magenta background. The screen displays what appears to be a media or content viewing interface with a large pink rectangular area taking up most of the screen. This demonstrates full-bleed content extending to the edges of the display while respecting the Dynamic Island at the top and safe areas.

content.text: People can freely resize windows down to a minimum width and height, similar to window behavior in macOS. It's important to account for this resizing behavior and the full range of possible window sizes when designing your layout. For guidance, see Multitasking and Windows.

content.guideline: As someone resizes a window, defer switching to a compact view for as long as possible.
content.explanation: Design for a full-screen view first, and only switch to a compact view when a version of the full layout no longer fits. This helps the UI feel more stable and familiar in as many situations as possible. For more complex layouts such as split views, prefer hiding tertiary columns such as inspectors as the view narrows.

content.guideline: Test your layout at common system-provided sizes, and provide smooth transitions.
content.explanation: Window controls provide the option to arrange windows to fill halves, thirds, and quadrants of the screen, so it's important to check your layout at each of these sizes on a variety of devices. Be sure to minimize unexpected UI changes as people adjust down to the minimum and up to the maximum window size.

content.guideline: Consider a convertible tab bar for adaptive navigation.
content.explanation: For many apps, you don't need to choose between a tab bar or sidebar for navigation; instead, you can adopt a style of tab bar that provides both. The app first launches with your choice of a sidebar or a tab bar, and then people can tap to switch between them. As the view resizes, the presentation style changes to fit the width of the view. For guidance, see Tab bars. For developer guidance, see sidebarAdaptable.

content.guideline: Avoid placing controls or critical information at the bottom of a window.
content.explanation: People often move windows so that the bottom edge is below the bottom of the screen.

content.guideline: Avoid displaying content within the camera housing at the top edge of the window.
content.explanation: For developer guidance, see NSPrefersDisplaySafeAreaCompatibilityMode.

content.description: An iPad screenshot showing a three-column layout interface. The left column shows a narrow sidebar with navigation items. The middle column displays a list of items (appears to be a content list or file browser). The right column shows a large pink/magenta content area representing the main content or detail view. This demonstrates the split-view/multi-column layout capabilities of iPadOS.
content.purpose: Demonstrates iPadOS multi-column layout and window resizing

content.text: No additional considerations for macOS. Check out the Design overview to learn about the fundamental design principles for macOS.

content.guideline: Be prepared for a wide range of TV sizes.
content.explanation: On Apple TV, layouts don't automatically adapt to the size of the screen like they do on iPhone or iPad. Instead, apps and games show the same interface on every display. Take extra care in designing your layout so that it looks great in a variety of screen sizes.

content.guideline: Adhere to the screen's safe area.
content.explanation: Inset primary content 60 points from the top and bottom of the screen, and 80 points from the sides. It can be difficult for people to see content that close to the edges, and unintended cropping can occur due to overscanning on older TVs. Allow only partially displayed offscreen content and elements that deliberately flow offscreen to appear outside this zone.

content.guideline: Include appropriate padding between focusable elements.
content.explanation: When you use UIKit and the focus APIs, an element gets bigger when it comes into focus. Consider how elements look when they're focused, and make sure you don't let them overlap important information. For developer guidance, see About focus interactions for Apple TV.

developerReferences.name: About focus interactions for Apple TV

content.text: The following grid layouts provide an optimal viewing experience. Be sure to use appropriate spacing between unfocused rows and columns to prevent overlap when an item comes into focus.

If you use the UIKit collection view flow element, the number of columns in a grid is automatically determined based on the width and spacing of your content. For developer guidance, see UICollectionViewFlowLayout.

content.tableSummary: Specifications for a two-column grid layout on tvOS, including content width of 860 points, horizontal spacing of 40 points, and minimum vertical spacing of 100 points.

content.guideline: Include additional vertical spacing for titled rows.
content.explanation: If a row has a title, provide enough spacing between the bottom of the previous unfocused row and the center of the title to avoid crowding. Also provide spacing between the bottom of the title and the top of the unfocused items in the row.

content.guideline: Use consistent spacing.
content.explanation: When content isn't consistently spaced, it no longer looks like a grid and it's harder for people to scan.

content.guideline: Make partially hidden content look symmetrical.
content.explanation: To help direct attention to the fully visible content, keep partially hidden offscreen content the same width on each side of the screen.

content.text: The guidance below can help you lay out content within the windows of your visionOS app or game, making it feel familiar and easy to use. For guidance on displaying windows in space and best practices for using depth, scale, and field of view in your visionOS app, see Spatial layout. To learn more about visionOS window components, see Windows > visionOS.
When you add depth to content in a standard window, the content extends beyond the window's bounds along the z-axis. If content extends too far along the z-axis, the system clips it.

content.guideline: Consider centering the most important content and controls in your app or game.
content.explanation: Often, people can more easily discover and interact with content when it's near the middle of a window, especially when the window is large.

content.guideline: Keep a window's content within its bounds.
content.explanation: In visionOS, the system displays window controls just outside a window's bounds in the XY plane. For example, the Share menu appears above the window and the controls for resizing, moving, and closing the window appear below it. Letting 2D or 3D content encroach on these areas can make the system-provided controls, especially those below the window, difficult for people to use.

content.guideline: If you need to display additional controls that don't belong within a window, use an ornament.
content.explanation: An ornament lets you offer app controls that remain visually associated with a window without interfering with the system-provided controls. For example, a window's toolbar and tab bar appear as ornaments. For guidance, see Ornaments.

content.guideline: Make a window's interactive components easy for people to look at.
content.explanation: You need to include enough space around an interactive component so that visually identifying it is easy and comfortable, and to prevent the system-provided hover effect from obscuring other content. For example, place buttons so their centers are at least 60 points apart. For guidance, see Eyes, Spatial layout, and Buttons > visionOS.

content.guideline: Design your content to extend from one edge of the screen to the other.
content.explanation: The Apple Watch bezel provides a natural visual padding around your content. To avoid wasting valuable space, consider minimizing the padding between elements.

content.guideline: Avoid placing more than two or three controls side by side in your interface.
content.explanation: As a general rule, display no more than three buttons that contain glyphs — or two buttons that contain text — in a row. Although it's usually better to let text buttons span the full width of the screen, two side-by-side buttons with short text labels can also work well, as long as the screen doesn't scroll.

content.guideline: Support autorotation in views people might want to show others.
content.explanation: When people flip their wrist away, apps typically respond to the motion by sleeping the display, but in some cases it makes sense to autorotate the content. For example, a wearer might want to show an image to a friend or display a QR code to a reader. For developer guidance, see isAutorotating.

content.description: An Apple Watch screenshot showing a watchOS app interface. The watch face displays a time of '10:09' at the top. Below that is a text label and a button labeled 'Text Button'. The interface demonstrates the compact layout principles for watchOS with edge-to-edge content and minimal spacing between elements. The Apple Watch shown has a rounded rectangular display with the characteristic watchOS UI styling.
content.purpose: Demonstrates watchOS layout principles including edge-to-edge content and button sizing

content.tableSummary: Complete list of iOS and iPadOS device screen dimensions showing model names with their dimensions in points and pixels, including scale factors (@2x or @3x).

content.text: All scale factors in the table above are UIKit scale factors, which may differ from native scale factors. For developer guidance, see scale and nativeScale.

A size class is a value that's either regular or compact, where regular refers to a larger screen or a screen in landscape orientation and compact refers to a smaller screen or a screen in portrait orientation. For developer guidance, see UserInterfaceSizeClass.
Different size class combinations apply to the full-screen experience on different devices, based on screen size.

content.tableSummary: Complete list of iOS and iPadOS device size classes showing model names with their size class combinations for both portrait and landscape orientations. iPads have regular width and regular height in both orientations. iPhones have compact width and regular height in portrait. In landscape, larger iPhones (Plus/Pro Max models) have regular width while standard models have compact width; all iPhones have compact height in landscape.
Complete list of watchOS device screen dimensions showing Apple Watch series, case sizes in millimeters, and screen dimensions in pixels. Covers Ultra (1st-3rd gen), Series 1-11, and SE models.

sections.title: Layout Introduction
sections.summary: Introduces layout concepts and the importance of consistent, adaptive design across Apple platforms.

sections.title: Best practices
sections.summary: Guidelines for grouping content, making information easy to find, extending content to fill screens, and differentiating controls from content using Liquid Glass.

sections.title: Visual hierarchy
sections.summary: Guidelines for placing items by importance, alignment, progressive disclosure, and spacing controls appropriately.

sections.title: Adaptability
sections.summary: Handling device and system variations including screen sizes, orientations, Dynamic Island, Display Zoom, Dynamic Type, and internationalization.

sections.title: Guides and safe areas
sections.summary: Defines layout guides and safe areas, explains their importance for avoiding system features and interactive components.

sections.title: Platform considerations - iOS
sections.summary: iOS-specific guidance including orientation support, full-bleed interfaces, button placement, and status bar visibility.

sections.title: Platform considerations - iPadOS
sections.summary: iPadOS-specific guidance for window resizing, compact view transitions, convertible tab bars, and camera housing considerations.

sections.title: Platform considerations - tvOS
sections.summary: tvOS-specific guidance for TV size ranges, safe areas (60pt top/bottom, 80pt sides), focus states, and grid layouts.

sections.title: Platform considerations - visionOS
sections.summary: visionOS-specific guidance for window content bounds, z-axis depth, ornaments, and interactive component spacing (60pt minimum).

sections.title: Platform considerations - watchOS
sections.summary: watchOS-specific guidance for edge-to-edge content, control limits (2-3 side by side), and autorotation support.

semanticStructure.documentFlow: The document begins with an introduction to layout principles, then covers best practices and visual hierarchy. It progresses through adaptability concerns, guides/safe areas, and then provides platform-specific considerations for each Apple platform (iOS, iPadOS, macOS, tvOS, visionOS, watchOS). The specifications section provides comprehensive device dimension and size class tables. The document concludes with resources and a detailed change log.

keyTerms.definition: A rectangular region that helps you position, align, and space your content on the screen.
The area within a view that isn't covered by a toolbar, tab bar, or other views a window might provide.
A value that's either regular or compact, where regular refers to a larger screen or a screen in landscape orientation and compact refers to a smaller screen or a screen in portrait orientation.
A material that provides a distinct appearance for controls that's consistent across iOS, iPadOS, and macOS.
A feature that lets people choose the size of visible text in iOS, iPadOS, tvOS, visionOS, and watchOS.
An interactive display feature on modern iPhones that apps need to accommodate.
A technique to help people discover content that's currently hidden.
In visionOS, a way to offer app controls that remain visually associated with a window without interfering with system-provided controls.
An interface that fills the screen while accommodating corner radius, sensor housing, and features like Dynamic Island.
A navigation style that provides both tab bar and sidebar functionality, allowing users to switch between them.

keyFindings: All iPads have Regular width and Regular height in both portrait and landscape orientations
All iPhones have Compact width and Regular height in portrait orientation
Larger iPhones (Plus and Pro Max models) have Regular width in landscape; standard models have Compact width
tvOS safe area insets: 60 points top/bottom, 80 points from sides
visionOS interactive components should have centers at least 60 points apart
watchOS should have no more than 3 glyph buttons or 2 text buttons in a row
